social_posts.post_text:
Kimberly and I started working together in September 2022.

And, as you can see, she absolutely f*cking CRUSHED her first 12 weeks.

Kimberly is married, has 2 young kids, and she has a demanding job that involves travel most months.

She’s done several things very well since we started working together:

1. She focuses on strength training as her primary form of exercise.

2. She started making it a priority to get her steps each and every day.

3. She plans ahead: steps, workouts, meals out, etc. Kimberly knows that her busy lifestyle means she can’t leave things to chance.

4. She’s completely changed her mindset and language around food. Food is no longer “good” or “bad”. She doesn’t limit certain foods to the weekend. She enjoys eating the same meals as her family. Kimberly has worked hard on implementing the 80/20 guideline, and now she has far more control over her food intake, whether she’s at home, at a restaurant, or on a work trip.

5. She’s focused on consistency over perfection. Kimberly knows she doesn’t need to be perfect with her habits, which has been liberating. She focuses on consistency, which means getting it done at least 80% of the time - which has made her feel far more relaxed about the process.

As a result of Kimberly’s hard work and consistency, she lost 9 lbs and 16.75 inches in our first 12 weeks!

She’s stronger.

She’s leaner.

And she’s regained her confidence.

Kimberly, CONGRATULATIONS on putting in the work and seeing such fantastic results. I’m looking forward to working with you for another 5 months!
 
 
 
 
#weightlosssuccess #weightlosssuccessstory #weightlosscoach #weightlosscoaching #weightlossprogress #weightlossgoals #weightlossformoms #weightlossforwomen

I was in Prague with my wife last week.

On our way to the hotel, we asked our taxi driver how far the walk was from our hotel in the Old Town to Prague Castle.

He immediately said “no, you can’t walk there, it takes a long time and it’s a very steep climb. Everyone takes the tram.”

Well, my wife and I decided to try anyway.

And we made it there on foot just f*cking fine - it was a really nice walk.

Was it a steep climb? Yes, steeper than most city walks. And I can see how someone who doesn’t regularly exercise would find it challenging, maybe even impossible, to do.

Which brings me on to the quote from Jerzy Gregorek (Tim Ferriss’ and Naval Ravikant’s personal trainer). “Hard choices, easy life. Easy choices, hard life.”

You see, I used to make the easy choices: not working out, not exercising, not getting enough sleep. And I suffered because of it: I would get winded easily, I was always tired, and I often had a “foggy” head. 

Now I regularly make the hard choices: consistent workouts, lots of daily steps, and a good bedtime routine. As a result, I can do pretty much anything I feel like doing and not worry that my body can’t handle it.

Yes, the human body doesn’t last forever, but I’m setting myself up for another few decades of being able to do what I want because I continue to make the hard choices.

That’s freedom.

And you can have it too - you just need to start making more hard choices.

You’ve got this.

Ok, I confess…

These truths aren’t really that harsh if you know me and you’ve been following me for a while.

Although they sure might sound a little harsh if you’re used to the usual BS I see on social media around weight loss.

But the truth sets you free.

And hopefully these truths will help you approach weight loss in a healthy and sustainable way, focusing on the areas that matter most.

❤️
 
 
 
 
#weightlossadvice #weightlosstips #weightlosstipsforwomen #weightlossforwomen #fatlossadvice #fatlosstips #healthyweightloss #sustainableweightloss

Trying to be perfect while losing weight never ends well.

Because perfection is impossible.

Life will always get in the way of the perfect plan.

ESPECIALLY if you have a job, spouse, kids, and pets (yes, I know not everyone has those things. I’m just describing the majority of my clients.)

You won’t be able to perfectly follow *any* plan.

Now listen: the logical conclusion to that should NOT be “so why even try?”

It shouldn’t make you feel limited.

It should make you feel LIBERATED.

It should make you realize that aiming for perfection just might be what’s holding you back from losing weight.

That you DON’T need to hit EVERY habit EVERY day.

That you can relax your “rules” from time to time and see results.

Aim for 80%. Get your sh*t done 80% of the time, don’t go totally overboard the other 20%, and you’ll still get results.

So stop trying to be perfect, because life has a way of stopping that.

Forget about following the “perfect” plan.

Stop feeling like a failure - because you’re NOT a failure.

And see results while feeling positive about the process.

 
 
 
 
 
#sustainableweightloss #weightlossadvice #fatlossadvice #healthyweightloss #healthyweightlossjourney #gettinginshape #losingweightjourney #losingweightmotivation

When a client tells me they’re having trouble hitting their protein goals…

I give them this to do as homework.

Because the solution to eating more protein can often be to simply eat bigger portions of the high-protein foods you’re already eating, while decreasing the serving size of everything else so you don’t go over calories (and making sure you’re still getting at least 20% of calories from fat).

It can be tough to hit the protein target I generally recommend of 0.7-1g protein per lb target weight.

(So someone with a goal weight 150 lbs should aim for 105-150g protein per day)

And if you’re not used to eating larger servings of protein, then this very simple solution won’t necessarily seem obvious.

But once you’ve tried it, hitting those protein goals doesn’t feel as difficult any more.

❤️
 
 
 
 
#howtoeatmoreprotein #proteinfood #highprotein #highproteindiet #weightlossadvice #fatlossadvice #weightlosshelp #weightlosscoach #nutritiontip #nutritioncoach

If you want to lose weight AND keep it off…

Then I would LOVE IT if you adopted the following mindset:
 
 
✅ Nutrition burns fat.

I want you to pretty much FORGET that exercise burns calories.

Because then you’ll stop relying on it for weight loss results.

Now…

You should OBVIOUSLY work out while trying to lose weight, and OF COURSE workouts burn calories. But please STOP trying to figure out how many calories you burn per workout and then adding it to your TDEE while dividing by the square root of your BMR, or whatever overly complicated math you’re trying to do.

Keep it simple: focus on NUTRITION for weight loss by making sure you’re eating at a small calorie deficit.

Which you can calculate by taking your target weight in lbs and multiplying by 12.

Eat that many calories per day.

This assumes you’re working out 3-5x per week and you get 7K+ steps per day.
 
 
✅ Strength training preserves muscle.

You need to strength train while you eat at a calorie deficit.

Because that’s gonna ensure you preserve your lean muscle, which will keep your metabolism high.

Plus you’ll get the “toned” look that so many people want.

And you WON’T get bulky - not if you’re eating at a calorie deficit.

A couple of 30-60 minutes workouts per week is a good minimum.
 
 
✅ Cardio improves overall health.

Cardio is a good idea. It improves cardiovascular health and overall conditioning levels.

Do cardio for the above reasons. NOT because it burns calories.

In fact, working out purely for the calories burned probably won’t do your relationship with exercise any favours.
 
 
 ✅ Walking reduces stress and helps recovery

Yes, it also burns calories, but “it burns calories” isn’t going to keep you consistent with this habit.

Doing it for stress management and workout recovery is gonna keep you more consistent.

And don’t try to turn it into a workout by wearing ankle weights or trying to hit a certain target heart rate - doing that won’t give the benefits I just mentioned.

❤️
 
 
 
 
#weightlossmindset #weightlosscoach #fatlosstip #weightlosstip #weightlossformoms #weightlossforwomen #weightlossformen #strengthtrainingforfatloss #strengthtrainingforwomen

Tell me if this sounds familiar...

You decide you’re going to take action and lose weight on Monday.

Great 🙌

So you tell yourself you’re going to “clean up” your diet, get rid of all the “bad” food, and only eat “clean” food.

So you do just that.

And you last MAYBE a week before you start fantasizing about all the “bad” food you’re no longer allowed, and before you know it you’ve eaten an entire pizza, crushed a bottle of Cola, and swallowed a pint of Ben and Jerry’s.

I’ve been there.

This is what happens when you demonize food, when you think about food in terms of “good” and “bad”, when you tell yourself you “aren’t allowed” certain foods.

It’s a recipe for disaster.

Look.

Food is food. Some of it is more nutritious, some of it is less nutritious.

Get at least 80% of your calories from more nutritious food, and up to 20% from less nutritious food.

Notice how much more relaxed you feel.
 
How you’re feeling fewer cravings.

And watch how much easier it is to maintain that calorie deficit ❤️
 
 
P.S. if this post looks familiar, there are a couple of reasons why:

1. I repost it every couple of months because I think we all need the reminder.

2. It’s one of my most shared posts.

3. It’s one of my most plagiarized posts 😂
 
 
 
 
#flexibledieting #caloriedeficit #weightlossfoods #nutritiontip #nutritiontips #fatlosshelp #flexibleeating #flexiblediet #sustainableweightloss #healthyweightloss #howtoloseweight #weightlosshelp

If this discourages you, you’re missing the point.

This post should actually ENCOURAGE you.

Because nobody’s weight loss journey is perfect.

Including yours.

Including my clients’ journey.

And including mine.

Nobody is out there crushing every workout.

Nobody loses weight EVERY week.

EVERYONE finds this difficult.

EVERYONE has been at that point where they wanted to say “f*ck it” and quit.

But when you realize this is all normal, you realize it’s part of the process.

(as long as you aren’t doing something extreme like eliminating food groups or doing 5 HIIT workouts per week or following an extremely low-calorie diet or working out EVERY day 👈 these are just a few of the things I would NEVER recommend)

And if it’s part of the process, then it’ll be easier to accept. And if you accept it and do it anyway, you’ll have a MUCH higher chance of success.

So don’t f*cking quit because you had a bad workout or your weight hasn’t moved this week.

As a parent and a business owner, I I can confirm: real life will make a perfect week impossible.

Remind yourself that it’s normal.

Remind yourself that you simply need to keep going and push through the frustration.

Remind yourself that if you’re totally exhausted, you’re allowed to - and should - do a lower-intensity version of the workout you had planned.

And remind yourself that you’ve got this ❤️
 
 
 
 
 
#weightlossadvice #weightlosshelp #healthyweightloss #healthyweightlossjourney #weightlossfacts #gettinginshape #sustainableweightlossjourney #losingweightjourney #losingweightishard #fitnessadvice

Beforeyou get mad, read the caption 👇

A few notes and caveats…

- Yes, some people are truly too busy. And for others, life is truly too stressful to start now. I, obviously, don’t know you or your situation. Only *you* will be able to look at your situation and know whether you’re a genuine exception or whether you’re just making excuses. If you’re a genuine exception, I sincerely wish you well while you figure it out.

- Google Calendar is a fantastic app for scheduling everything: workouts, steps, meal prep, etc. Scheduling these things WILL increase your chance of doing them and being successful.

- As we age we accrue responsibilities - families, sedentary jobs, etc. - that make it a lot harder to get enough movement and to choose to eat well *without conscious effort*. It’s these things that make it seem like our metabolism has slowed, when our metabolism is actually fine - it’s our *habits* that are the issue.

- Many of my peri-menopausal clients have told me in great detail how rough menopause is: the hot flashes, sleep problems, mood changes, and other symptoms sound tough to say the least. And, according to the study I mentioned, it’s more likely that these symptoms are to blame for menopausal weight gain than changes in metabolism - after all, if you’re going through all that, I can only imagine how difficult it must be to choose to eat healthy and exercise with a high degree of consistency.

- There are definitely exceptions to the above. Plenty of women (and men) under 60 have experienced a genuine slowing of their metabolism due to severe hormonal disruptions (whether menopause-related or not). For example, I’ve worked with many clients living with thyroid issues - for them, their metabolism *is* slow when they’re not being properly medicated. If you suspect you have a hormone issue like this, please talk to your doctor.

- It’s totally cool to increase calories up to maintenance on weekends. But if you treat the weekend as a complete free-for-all you’re going to find it hard to get results.
 
 
 
 
 
#weightlossadvice #weightlosstipsforwomen #weightlossforwomen #weightlossformoms

Some things on the list might surprise you. And some you might have heard before.

Will following these guidelines give you rapid results?

Nope.

But will these guidelines give you long-term and sustainable results that will also help you develop a healthy relationship with food and exercise?

Abso-f*cking-lutely they will.

This applies to Dads too.

And anyone else taking care of kids.

But I’ve noticed that it tends to be Moms who say this more than Dads.

Look…

It isn’t selfish to spend time going for walks or prepping healthy meals.

It isn’t selfish to spend money on a gym membership.

It isn’t selfish to spend money on workout equipment.

Sure, stick to your budget and make sure you’re still spending time with your family, but the idea that doing 2-4 30-45 minute workouts per week at a local gym (or in your basement) is selfish is totally wrong.

A healthier parent is a more present and engaged parent.

A healthier parent can run around and play sports with their kids.

A healthier parent has a better chance of being around for long enough to do the above with their grandkids.

In other words…

If YOU get healthier, EVERYBODY wins.

You’re not being selfish by trying to get healthier.

You’re being an awesome parent ❤️
 
 
 
 
#fitnesstip #fitnesstipsforwomen #fitnessformoms #workouttip #gettinginshape #workoutadvice #fitnessadvice

Social media is super f*cking misleading.

It’ll have you thinking that if you’re not crushing 10,000 steps every day, doing intense HIIT workouts, and eating high-protein gourmet meals, then you might as well not bother.

F*ck that.

F*ck that even harder if you’re new to all this and you’re feeling super overwhelmed.

Here’s what you actually need to do if you’re a beginner: do ONE thing every day to demonstrate to yourself that you’re the kind of person who takes action when you want to achieve your goals.

Maybe it’s a 5-minute walk.

Maybe it’s drinking a glass of water.

Maybe it’s eating a piece of fruit.

I don’t actually give a f*ck WHAT it is. You just gotta do SOMETHING.

So please: stop waiting to start until you’ve found the “perfect” plan, because that doesn’t exist. Do one small, achievable thing today.

And do it again tomorrow.

❤️
 
 
 
 
#weightlosshabits #fatlosshabits #weightlossmindset #sustainableweightloss #weightlosscoach #weightlosscoaching #weightlosstip #weightlossadvice #sustainableweightloss #healthyweightloss

There’s always SOMETHING.

There’s always a reason NOT to start:

- it’s too hot in summer
- too cold in winter
- work’s too busy
- the kids have too much going on
- there are too many social events now the weather’s better

…

Waiting for the perfect time to start makes no sense, because there will NEVER be a perfect time.

So just start.

Go for a walk.

Drink a glass of water.

Join a gym.

Eat veggies with your next meal.

Eat protein with your next meal.

Do a few bicep curls.

Start a food journal.

Meditate for 3 minutes.

Hire a coach.

Cut back on booze.

Go to bed early.

Work out tomorrow morning before the rest of your family gets up.

F*ck it, work out NOW.

☝️ Pick one of the above and go do it. Prove to yourself that you’re serious about finally making that change.

You’ve got this ❤️
 
 
 
 
#workoutadvice #gettinginshape #workouttip #weightlosscoach #weightlosscoaching #fitnessadvice #fitnesstip #weightlossadvice #fatlosstip

Look…

👉 Being sore does not mean the workout will provide better results than one that didn’t make you sore, assuming you worked just as hard in each workout. Soreness just means you did something that’s fairly new. Work hard, but don’t think you need to be crushed.

👉 A workout should never cause “bad” pain. You know, joint pain, sharp pain, or any kind of pain that just feels “wrong”.

👉 And if a workout makes you throw up, that’s not good. It means it was beyond what you’re currently capable of.

A workout, even a tough one, should make you feel energized and ready to take on the world.

👉 If you’re following a plan based on a celebrity or athlete’s plan, you might wanna consider throwing it out.

Because when Johnny F*ckface is in training to play the next Captain Who-Gives-A-Sh*t, he has a personal trainer, a personal chef, no injuries, and literally nothing to do except train, eat, and sleep.

You’re 40, you have kids, a full-time job, and sleep ain’t great. You CAN still get awesome results, but your program is going to be different to Mr F*ckface’s because you have way more things to take into account.

If you try the Johnny F*ckface program, it won’t end well.

👉 When it comes to strength training, simple is usually better. And one that’s based on your individual movement abilities is best.
 
 
If you’re new to strength training, go to rosentrain.com/strength and subscribe to my newsletter - I’ll immediately send you my FREE Beginner’s Guide to Strength Training pdf, which will explain what a beginner-friendly program would look like.

❤️

Weight loss is f*cking slow.

You need to be patient.

And patience is challenging for many of us.

In fact, lack of patience is a super common reason for giving up.

You need to give it more than a couple of weeks.

So use these tips to make you more patient AND actually feel good about the process ❤️
 
 
 
 
#gettinginshape #fitnesstips #weightlossstruggle #weightlossadvice #weightlosstips #weightlosscoaching #fatlosstips #fatlossadvice #weightlossforwomen #weightlossformoms

This is called an *abundance mindset*

An abundance mindset will make your weight loss journey so much more sustainable and misery-free.

So instead of focusing on a ridiculously low and ARBITRARY calorie intake like 1200 calories, here’s what you’re gonna do:

- take your target weight in lbs
- multiply by 12
- eat that many calories per day, plus or minus 100 calories

Don’t think of it as your “maximum” calorie goal; instead, your daily mission is to eat within 100 calories of that number.

So if your goal is 150 lbs, your target is 1800 (150 x 12) calories per day.

And your daily range is 1700-1900 calories per day.

Finish each day in that range while also getting 7K+ steps per day, strength training 2-3x per week, and doing some cardio - and you’ll have a better chance of being consistent enough for long enough to see results.

If you try to force yourself to stick with fewer calories than your range and you’re chronically hungry, stop. That isn’t a “better” day - you’re just making things harder than they need to be, and you’ll be more likely to overeat in the near future future, undoing any kind of progress you made.

But a day where you finish within your range and you feel satiated - that’s a f*cking win. You can keep that up for a damn long time - long enough to see results ❤️
 
 
P.S. if this sounds like it won’t be enough calories (because, for example, you’re super active) then eat a little more and see how you feel. If this sounds like too many calories, what do you have to lose by trying? You can adjust as needed if you don’t see results.
 

P.P.S. this means some smaller people might need to aim for approx 1200 cals - basically anyone with a target weight of 100 lbs, which also means you’ll be around 5’0” tall. If that describes you and 1200 sounds horrible, consider increasing steps to 10-15K and add an additional 100-300 cals.
 
 
P.P.P.S this is a general formula that won’t work for EVERYONE. You don’t need to point out the f*cking obvious. 

 
 
 
#weightlossadvice #weightlossmindset #abundancemindset #weightlosshelp #caloriedeficitdiet #fatlosstip #weightlosstip #weightlosstipsforwomen #fatlossadvice #weightlosscoach #weightlossformoms

Whether you lose weight or not…

Think about how many benefits you’ll see from doing those things.

The health benefits.

The confidence.

The sense of feeling ready to take on just about anything.

And once you have these habits in place - adding a calorie deficit will suddenly feel far more manageable.
 
 
 
 
#weightlossadvice #caloriedeficitdiet #caloriedeficit #caloriecounting #fatlosstip #fatlossadvice #strengthtrainingforwomen

“Starvation mode” - the claim that being in too big a calorie deficit makes your body store calories as fat - isn’t real.

There’s zero evidence.

It’s a myth.

No study has ever provided indisputable evidence that underfeeding somebody resulted in fat gain while they were in a calorie deficit, unless there was a pre-existing disorder present such as lipedema (don’t ask, just google it).

And so while it’s 100% true that undereating can lead to weight gain, it’s because periods of undereating almost always lead to periods of OVEReating.

Think about it: when your calorie intake is arbitrarily low - usually somewhere around 1200 calories, which is too low for anyone except very small people - your body literally thinks it’s starving. And it responds with a massive hunger cue to make you go out and find - and eat - as much food as possible.

In other words, It’s the accompanying period of overeating that causes the weight gain.

And while there is the fact that your body will spontaneously reduce your overall movement (you’ll literally fidget less) in a calorie deficit, this isn’t starvation mode - this is called “metabolic adaptation” and you can override it by simply choosing to move around more. Having a daily steps goal will help.

Eating too few calories can also lead to muscle loss and an eventual slower metabolism if you do it for too long (talk to your doctor if you think this describes you) which is another reason why eating too few calories is a bad idea.

So please, stop trying to get by on so few calories.

Target weight in lbs x12 is a much more reasonable calorie goal (assuming you’re getting 7K+ steps per day and working out 3-5x per week. If you don’t, start introducing these habits).

And watch your consistency increase and your inches decrease.
 
 
 
 
#weightlosscoach #weightlossmyths #weightlossmyth #weightlossadvice #weightlosshelp #fatlossadvice #fatlosstip #weightlossstruggle #weightlosscoaching #nutritionadvice #weightlossadvice

Here’s why 👇

1. If you don’t track the small things like cream in coffee, small bites of your kid’s food, and cooking oil, you could easily be eating HUNDREDS of calories more than you realize.

2. Calorie quality is important. I’m not disputing that. Eat your veggies, healthy fats, and lean protein. But if you eat too many calories of nutritious food, you won’t see results.

3. Sure, you can go up to maintenance on weekends if you want. But if you completely ignore your calorie intake on weekends, you can EASILY undo the work you did during the week.

4. All trackers overestimate how many calories you burned. Also, eating exercise calories and working out just because it burns calories is a NOT a good way of developing a healthy relationship with exercise - OR food. Target weight in lbs x12 assumes you’re getting 7-10K steps per day and working out 3-5x per week - so you don’t need to worry about calculating exercise calories.

5. Getting your daily 7-10K steps is a very important part of fat loss. But don’t focus on the calorie-burning part of it. Focus on the stress relief that walking gives you, the chance to listen to some music or a podcast, or the opportunity it gives you to spend time with someone you love without being distracted by a screen.

6. If you try to guess portion sizes, you WILL underestimate. If you’re not seeing results, try using a food scale, measuring cups, and measuring spoons to see how accurate your guesses were.
 
 
If you found this post useful, please share it with a friend ❤️
 
 
 
 
 
#fatlosstips #fatlossadvice #weightlosstips #weightlossadvice #weightlossplateau #weightlosscoach #nutritiontips #nutritioncoaching #healthyweightloss #sustainableweightloss

Listen: I’m not saying you *should* overeat by 1000 calories 6x per month.

I’m not an advocate for “cheat days”. I’m an advocate for moderation. I’m simply saying you would still see results if you slipped up 6 times in 30 days and overate by 1000 calories.

Anyway. Let’s do the math…

24 days a month you manage to end the day at a deficit of around 500 calories.

Nice work 👊

24 x 500 = 12,000. This is your total deficit those days.

The other days you overeat by a thousand calories, ending the day at a surplus of 500 calories (your goal is a 500-cal deficit, you overshoot by 1000, you end up with a 500-cal surplus).

6 x 500 = 3000.

Your net deficit for those 30 days is:

12,000 - 3000 = 9000 calories.

Which means you can still lose over 2 pounds of fat in that period even with 6 “f*ckups”.

Sure, the scale might not budge, but that’ll be due to the extra water retention from those days. Getting back on track is all you need to do to get rid of the extra water.

And this is the power of consistency over perfection. If you can be on point 80% of the time, it’s very hard to undo that work the remaining 20% of the time. Plus it will REALLY help remove some of the rigidity you may be feeling with your diet - flexibility usually helps us feel more relaxed about the process, which can be huge for developing the mindset of sustainability.

The key is to not let the occasional day where you slip up turn into WEEKS of slipping up. If you’re currently in this position after the holiday weekend, remember, you’re just one decision away from getting back on track.

👉 Please SHARE this post to your Story if you think one of your perfectionist followers would benefit from seeing it 🙏

❤️

Happy Friday ❤️

Use this post to take back control of your food intake this weekend.

The keyword here is PLANNING.

Leave nothing to chance.

And you’ll be fine 🙌
 
 
 
 
#weightlosstip #weightlossadvice #weightlosstips #nutritiontips #weightlosscoach #weightlosscoaching #fatlosstips #fatlosstip #weightlosshelp #flexiblediet

READ THE CAPTION👇

Notice what ISN’T on the list:

- Supplements
- HIIT workouts
- Intermittent fasting
- Ketosis
- The balance of fat and carbs (aside from getting no less than 20% of calories from fat - your carb/fat balance comes down to your individual needs and preferences)

And a bunch more stuff that almost no healthy person reading this needs to worry about.

Sure, it can be part of the plan if you enjoy it, but those things are minor details. They aren’t required for results.

Instead of focusing on the minor details, focus on the fundamentals.

Because for weight loss, focusing on the fundamentals and doing them consistently is what you need for results.

Quick note: I said do *some* cardio. Cardio isn’t that important for weight loss, but it’s important for health - so you should do some. 1-3 hours training in Zone 2 per week would be a nice eventual aim. Go look up @syattfitness ‘s podcasts about Zone 2 cardio for more information.

Also: don’t try to start everything on this list at the same time. That won’t end well. Focus on 1 habit at a time. When you have 1 in place (which can take anywhere from a few days to a few weeks) choose another to introduce.

NB: “elimination of favourite foods” is NOT on the list. Get 80+% of calories from nutritious food, and the rest from your favourite “less nutritious” sources.

Because you need to live life while losing weight.

And even if you’re not a beginner but you’d like to lose some weight, the rules don’t change. You don’t need anything extreme. You need a simple plan.

You also need to focus on your lifestyle outside of food and fitness - sleep, stress management, patience - whatever your status. Sleep is the foundation of everything, because everything feels easier when you’re well-rested.

So go to bed earlier and stop using your f*cking phone in bed.

❤️

When I say these things don’t take talent, I don’t mean they’re necessarily easy.

I’m simply pointing out that pretty much anyone can form these habits one by one with a few weeks - or months - of effort.
 
 
1. Pre-tracking food does two things. First it means you don’t need to pull out your phone and decide what to eat several times a day, saving you time and effort. And second, it means you’ll know if you’re in a calorie deficit or not for the day - it makes no f*cking sense to track your food AFTER eating it and finding out you went way over your calories. Block off time either the morning of or the night before to pre-track the coming day’s food.

2. The best way to get more sleep - which will lower levels of the hormone that makes you hungry (ghrelin) - is to simply go to bed earlier. Yes, I know that shift workers can’t be in bed by 10pm. I don’t literally mean go to bed by 10pm - I mean stop staying up so late. And don’t give me that “I need me time” sh*t - first, you don’t need 3 hours of “me time”. One hour is plenty. And second, going to bed earlier will probably give you time to work out in the morning. THAT can be your “me time”.

3. Scheduling your workouts is a way of committing to doing them. If you’re not currently being consistent with your workouts, do this. Just telling yourself you’ll figure it out on the day is why you’re not getting it done.

4. Having set meal times will regulate hunger. If you have regular meal times your body will soon learn when to expect food, and it will then start pumping out those hunger hormones at an appropriate time.

5. Stop using your f*cking phone in bed. Mindless scrolling will make your sleep quality worse, even if you have no problem falling asleep, because you’re overloading your brain with information when you’re supposed to be in a relaxed state - and a relaxed state is one where you’re not consuming large amounts of information. Stick with reading a book. Or consider some meditation or breathing exercises.

If you love boot camps, make that your focus. Again, great habit.

If you love Pilates, make that your focus. Pilates can be a great workout.

Enjoying the process makes the process more sustainable.

But whatever you do…

You need to strength train. At least 1-2x per week.

Strength training improves bone density.

It can improve flexibility and mobility.

It can improve your quality of life as you age.

And, for weight loss, it will help prevent muscle loss in a calorie deficit.

We could all do with more discipline.

But lack of discipline is rarely the issue with those who can’t lose weight. Sure, it’s SOMETIMES the issue, but it’s usually more about hunger and poor habits.

Here’s what to address…

- More fiber will help you feel full. Women need around 21-25g per day, and men need around 30-38g. Fiber basically means “more fruit and veggies”.

- Good sleep will increase levels of the hormone that make you feel full (leptin) and decreases levels of the hormone that makes you feel hungry (ghrelin).

- Protein is INCREDIBLE at reducing hunger. Aim for [target weight in lbs x 0.7-1] grams per day. So if your goal weight is 150 lbs, aim for 105-150g protein per day.

- Undereating will also increase hunger. Instead of eating 1200 calories, aim for [target weight in lbs x12] calories per day. Also, eat more of your damn calories at breakfast and lunch - it’s why you keep overeating at night.

- Have more flexibility with food; instead of trying to eliminate processed foods (which usually leads to overeating processed foods on the weekend) include a little of them several times a week (up to 20% of your daily intake).

- Daily movement and stress management are linked. Going for a daily walk is going to be huge for helping you manage stress, which can reduce stress eating. If that alone doesn’t work, try journaling, meditation, breathing exercises, or therapy.

Some caveats 👇

1. You can lose weight doing ANYTHING as long as you’re eating in a calorie deficit. But some methods are more sustainable than others.

2. I assume you’re focusing on nutrition as a way of getting into a calorie deficit.

3. I’m talking about SUSTAINABLE weight loss: losing the weight AND keeping it off long-term.

4. I’m advocating what works for MOST people. Individual mileage may vary.

5. You should be moderately active day-to-day, getting 7-10K steps per day and working out 3-5x per week.

Cool?

Cool.
 
 
❌ 🏋🏽🏋🏽🏋🏽

Lifting weights is awesome.

But what if I told you doing some mobility work and throwing in cardio from time to time would actually make you STRONGER.

Improved mobility = movement through a greater range of motion = more strength.

As for cardio: simply put, it’s great for your health.
 
 
❌ 🏃‍♂️🏃‍♂️🏃‍♂️

The problem with focusing on cardio without lifting weights is that you’ll eventually lose muscle.

You won’t look toned. To look toned you need enough muscle so give your body shape.
 
 
❌ 🧘🏾‍♀️🧘🏾‍♀️🧘🏾‍♀️

Focusing just on yoga (or Pilates) is another issue I see all the time, especially with those who are either scared that weights will make them bulky, or are too intimidated to lift weights.

Yoga has a TON of benefits. You should do it, or at least spend time doing mobility work on a consistent basis.

But it doesn’t have the same muscle-preserving or strength-building effects that strength training has. Nor does Pilates.
 
 
✅ 🏋🏽🧘🏾‍♀️🏃‍♂️

My favourite way of training for sustainable weight loss looks like this:

✅ Strength train 2-4x per week
✅ Cardio 1-3x per week, daily walking
✅ 5-10 mins of mobility work before workouts
✅ At least 1 day off per week where you focus on low-intensity walking and maybe some light mobility work

And look: if you wanna focus more on one kind of workout than another because you enjoy it more, awesome. Go for it.

Just don’t let “I don’t enjoy it” as an excuse to avoid doing what you need to do.

Read the caption 👇

I believe counting calories is a very efficient way of getting into a calorie deficit and losing weight.

I think it’s the MOST efficient way.

But it isn’t the ONLY way.

Tracking calories isn’t appropriate for everyone. Maybe it feels too tedious or it makes you too obsessive or you’re just not a numbers person.

If that describes you, this post is for you.

And by the way: this assumes you’re working out 3-5x per week and getting 7K+ steps per day. If you don’t do that - start.
 
 
✅ Eat 3 meals per day. 1/2 the plate should be covered by veggies, 1/4 by your protein source, and a 1/4 by your carb source. Stop eating when you’re 80% full (yes, this is subjective), eat slowly, and drink a glass of water before and after each meal.

If you’re concerned by the lack of mention of fat, bear in mind that most meat and fish contains plenty of fat anyway - and don’t forget about cooking oil. But feel free to add a little healthy fat 😊

Also: don’t cheat by buying a giant plate 😂
 
 
✅ Drink [half your bodyweight in lbs] oz water per day. That’s an approximate aim - individually requirements will vary. And most people probably won’t need more than 100oz.

Monitor your pee: dark orange = drink more water. Pale yellow = you’re good.

You can also drink black coffee, herbal tea, and zero-calorie soda as needed.
 
 
✅ Snacks and alcohol are fine in moderation. Although I don’t recommend having more than 1 drink every day - it’ll impact sleep.
 
 
✅ When in restaurants, ask for sauces and dressings on the side.

When in doubt, ask for a salad.

Skip dessert, unless you REALLY want it, in which case you can count it as 2 snacks.

And DON’T feel obligated to “get your money’s worth” and clear your plate. If you’re not hungry, stop eating.

And the same goes with ANY meal - stop eating if you’re no longer hungry.

Also: if you REALLY want the dessert AND some wine AND your snacks for the day… lol go ahead. Just get back on track tomorrow.

I used to believe everything on this list.

Which is why my results used to be temporary.

And why my weight yo-yo’d in my twenties.

It was only when I accepted that what I was doing wasn’t working that I was able to educate myself…

1) When calories are matched, meal frequency has no impact on either your metabolism or your rate of fat loss. Your total calorie intake determines your rate of fat loss.

2) Squats are only bad for your knees if you already have bad knees. And performing squats with sh*t technique is also bad for your knees.

3) When calories are matched, high carb and low carb diets lead to the same outcome. Your carb intake comes down to personal preference. Yes, some people experience increased appetite on a high carb diet. Others experience the opposite. And for others, it makes no difference.

4) The best thing for fat loss is a calorie deficit, whether you’re doing HIIT workouts or not.

5) As long as you’re in a calorie deficit, you could eat a sugar-only diet and still lose fat. Would that be a good idea? F*ck no. That would be a tremendously bad idea.You’ll be chronically hungry and your health will suffer enormously. Eat your fruit and veggies. But know that eating sugar in a calorie deficit will still lead to fat loss.

6) Your rate of sweating indicates your rate of effort and your temperature, which won’t have any impact on fat loss if you’re not in a calorie deficit. And if you’re in a calorie deficit, you’ll lose fat whether you sweat or not. Train for the right reasons: strength train to get stronger, do cardio for lung and heart health, and go on walks to manage stress. Not because “it burns calories”.

Here’s why…

1. Bulgarian split squats. Need I say more?

2. Having a “2-plate” deadlift, squat, or bench press refers to there being 2x 45 lb plates (weights)on EACH side of the bar. Then we add the weight of the bar, which is almost always 45 lbs. Total = 225 lbs.

3. Once you’ve started a program, stick to it! It’s been written with the intention of you following it for its full duration, which is what you would need to do for results. If you keep program hopping and changing exercises, you won’t be able to apply progressive overload consistently enough and long enough to get stronger and build muscle.

4. You don’t get stronger during a workout. You get stronger as you recover from it. And sleep is a HUGE part of recovery. If sleep is poor, you won’t recover enough to get stronger.

5. If I only trained when I was motivated to, I’d probably train no more than 1-2x per month. So I make myself train even when I’m not motivated to. How do I do that? By simply deciding to. And I remind myself that making the easy choice of not working out will NOT lead me to a good place, physically or mentally.

The rest of us will get MUCH better results if we focus on EITHER fat loss OR building muscle.

A few points for clarification…

- Yes, the quality of your food matters. The vast majority (at least 80%) of your food should be nutritious. But if you’re not in a calorie deficit, you won’t lose fat - no matter how nutrient-dense your diet is.

- Bands can be *part* of a booty-building program. But if you’re not also doing squats, lunges, deadlifts, and hip thrusts with weights, you won’t get the results you’re looking for.

- Beginners can effectively build muscle in a calorie deficit - for a couple of months. Then you really need to be at maintenance (or in a small surplus) to see growth. In other words, EITHER focus on losing fat OR building muscle. One goal at a time :)

- Please don’t ask me about metabolism not slowing down until you’re 60. I’ve literally given you a study reference. Type “PMID: 34385400” into Google and read the VERY easy to understand abstract for the study. You can also find the full text FOR FREE if you use the europepmc.org link, which I believe is the 2nd result in Google if you search for the above phrase. Stronger By Science has also written a good summary of the entire study (again, use your Google skills to find it). And the VERY obvious exception to this is having some kind of medical issue.

For most people, it isn’t that our metabolism decreases. It’s that our workout frequency decreases. Our step count decreases. And our consistency decreases - because with age comes more responsibilities. And responsibilities mean less time for movement. But that isn’t an excuse - it just means that we have to plan ahead more.

And if you’re over 60: don’t worry. The decline in metabolism is VERY slow, so you have no reason to stop trying.

You’re allowed to chill on weekends.

My clients do.

I do when I’m in a fat loss phase - which I actually just started yesterday.

We usually go up to maintenance on one or both weekend days.

But “going up to maintenance” doesn’t mean saying “f*ck it” and giving in to every indulgence.

And feeling that need to say “f*ck it” every weekend is an issue - there’s a good sign you’re being too rigid with your choices during the week, such as refusing to eat ANYTHING “less nutritious” until the weekend. Which is an excellent way of building up cravings for that kind of food to the point where you can’t control how much of it you eat when you DO allow yourself to consume it.

It could also be a sign you’re getting bored of your meals during the week - time to Google “high protein meals” and get creative.

Also, if you’re saying “f*ck it” for the entire weekend, you might just be consuming as many calories over 2 and a half days as you are over the other 4 and a half days. This is going to impact your ability to make progress.

So try to be less rigid during the week. Eat a random cookie on a Tuesday to prevent cravings from building up. Remember that being “80/20” doesn’t mean saving all the “less nutritious” food for the weekend. It can apply *every* day.

Which is how you can take back control of your nutrition habits.

Have a great weekend ❤️

If you wanna lose weight AND keep it off…

Then I would LOVE IT if you adopted the following mindset:
 
 
✅ Nutrition burns fat.

I want you to pretty much FORGET that exercise burns calories.

Because then you’ll stop relying on it for weight loss results.

Now…

You should OBVIOUSLY work out while trying to lose weight, and OF COURSE workouts burn calories. But please STOP trying to figure out how many calories you burn per workout and then adding it to your TDEE while dividing by the square root of your BMR, or whatever overly complicated math you’re trying to do.

Keep it simple: focus on NUTRITION for weight loss by making sure you’re eating at a small calorie deficit.

Which you can calculate by taking your target weight in lbs and multiplying by 12.

Eat that many calories per day.

This assumes you’re working out 3-5x per week and you get 7K+ steps per day.
 
 
✅ Strength training preserves muscle.

You need to strength train while you eat at a calorie deficit.

Because that’s gonna ensure you preserve your lean muscle, which will keep your metabolism high.

Plus you’ll get the “toned” look that so many people want.

And you WON’T get bulky - not if you’re eating at a calorie deficit.

A couple of 30-60 minutes workouts per week is a good minimum.
 
 
✅ Cardio improves overall health.

Cardio is a good idea. It improves cardiovascular health and overall conditioning levels.

Do cardio for the above reasons. NOT because it burns calories.

In fact, working out purely for the calories burned probably won’t do your relationship with exercise any favours.
 
 
 ✅ Walking reduces stress and helps recovery

Yes, it also burns calories, but “it burns calories” isn’t going to keep you consistent with this habit.

Doing it for stress management and workout recovery is gonna keep you more consistent.

And don’t try to turn it into a workout by wearing ankle weights or trying to hit a certain target heart rate - doing that won’t give the benefits I just mentioned.

A few notes and caveats…

- Yes, some people are genuinely too busy. And for others, life is truly too stressful to start now. I, obviously, don’t know you or your situation. Only *you* will be able to look at your situation and know whether you’re a genuine exception or whether you’re just making excuses. - As we age we accrue responsibilities - families, sedentary jobs, etc. - that make it a lot harder to get enough movement and to choose to eat well *without conscious effort*. It’s these things that make it seem like our metabolism has slowed, when our metabolism is actually fine - it’s our *habits* that are the issue.

- Many of my peri-menopausal clients have told me in great detail how rough menopause is: the hot flashes, sleep problems, mood changes, and other symptoms sound tough to say the least. And, according to the study I mentioned, it’s more likely that these symptoms are to blame for menopausal weight gain than changes in metabolism - after all, if you’re going through all that, I can only imagine how difficult it must be to choose to eat healthy and exercise with a high degree of consistency.

- There are definitely exceptions to the above. Plenty of women (and men) under 60 have experienced a genuine slowing of their metabolism due to severe hormonal disruptions (whether menopause-related or not). For example, I’ve worked with many clients living with thyroid issues - for them, their metabolism *is* slow when they’re not being properly medicated. If you suspect you have a hormone issue like this, please talk to your doctor.

- It’s totally cool to increase calories up to maintenance on weekends. But if you treat the weekend as a complete free-for-all you’re going to find it hard to get results.

This is called an *abundance mindset*

An abundance mindset will make your weight loss journey so much more sustainable and misery-free.

So instead of focusing on a ridiculously low and ARBITRARY calorie intake like 1200 calories, here’s what you’re gonna do:

- take your target weight in lbs
- multiply by 12
- eat that many calories per day, plus or minus 100 calories

Don’t think of it as your “maximum” calorie goal; instead, your daily mission is to eat within 100 calories of that number.

So if your goal is 150 lbs, your target is 1800 (150 x 12) calories per day.

And your daily range is 1700-1900 calories per day.

Finish each day in that range while also getting 7K+ steps per day, strength training 2-3x per week, and doing some cardio - and you’ll have a better chance of being consistent enough for long enough to see results.

If you try to force yourself to stick with fewer calories than your range and you’re chronically hungry, stop. That isn’t a “better” day - you’re just making things harder than they need to be, and you’ll be more likely to overeat in the near future future, undoing any kind of progress you made.

But a day where you finish within your range and you feel satiated - that’s a fucking win. You can keep that up for a damn long time - long enough to see results ❤️
 
 
P.S. if this sounds like it won’t be enough calories (because, for example, you’re super active) then eat a little more and see how you feel. If this sounds like too many calories, what do you have to lose by trying? You can adjust as needed if you don’t see results.
 

P.P.S. this means some smaller people might need to aim for approx 1200 cals - basically anyone with a target weight of 100 lbs, which also means you’ll be around 5’0” tall. If that describes you and 1200 sounds horrible, consider increasing steps to 10-15K and add an additional 100-300 cals.
 
 
P.P.P.S this is a general formula that won’t work for EVERYONE. You don’t need to point out the obvious.

“Starvation mode” - the claim that being in too big a calorie deficit makes your body store calories as fat - isn’t real.

There’s zero evidence.

It’s a myth.

No study has ever provided indisputable evidence that underfeeding somebody resulted in fat gain while they were in a calorie deficit, unless there was a pre-existing disorder present such as lipedema (google it).

And so while it’s 100% true that undereating can lead to weight gain, it’s because periods of undereating usually lead to periods of OVEReating.

Think about it: when your calorie intake is arbitrarily low - usually somewhere around 1200 calories, which is too low for anyone except very small people - your body literally thinks it’s starving. And it responds with a massive hunger cue to make you go out and find - and eat - as much food as possible.

In other words, It’s the accompanying period of overeating that causes the weight gain.

And while there is the fact that your body will spontaneously reduce your overall movement (you’ll literally fidget less) in a calorie deficit, this isn’t starvation mode - this is called “metabolic adaptation” and you can override it by simply making the conscious choice to move around more. Having a daily step goal will help.

Eating too few calories can also lead to muscle loss and an eventual slower metabolism if you do it for too long (talk to your doctor if you think this describes you) which is another reason why eating too few calories is a bad idea.

So please, stop trying to get by on so few calories.

Target weight in lbs x12 is a much more reasonable calorie goal (assuming you’re getting 7K+ steps per day and working out 3-5x per week. If you don’t, start introducing these habits).

And watch your consistency increase and your inches decrease.

Here’s why 👇

1. If you don’t track the small things like cream in coffee, small bites of your kid’s food, and cooking oil, you’re eating HUNDREDS of calories more than you realize.

2. Calorie quality is important. I’m not disputing that. Eat your veggies, healthy fats, and lean protein. But if you eat too many calories of nutritious food, you won’t see results.

3. Sure, you can go up to maintenance on weekends if you want. But if you completely ignore your calorie intake on weekends, you can EASILY undo the work you did during the week.

4. All trackers overestimate how many calories you burned. Also, eating exercise calories and working out just because it burns calories is a NOT a good way of developing a healthy relationship with exercise - OR food. Target weight in lbs x12 assumes you’re getting 7-10K steps per day and working out 3-5x per week - so you don’t need to worry about calculating exercise calories.

5. Getting your daily 7-10K steps is a very important part of fat loss. But don’t focus on the calorie-burning part of it. Focus on the stress relief that walking gives you, the chance to listen to some music or a podcast, or the opportunity it gives you to spend time with someone you love without being distracted by a screen.

6. If you try to guess portion sizes, you WILL underestimate. If you’re not seeing results, try using a food scale, measuring cups, and measuring spoons to see how accurate your guesses were.

I know some of these a might sound surprising…

Especially “be social” and “practice gratitude”.

But these two habits are so important for your psychological health.

Being social and practicing gratitude can hugely impact your stress levels.

And we all know that high stress means a higher chance of stress-induced overeating. So it’s a good idea to do what we can to manage stress.

For the introverts reading this, don’t misunderstand what I’m saying. I’m not saying you need to go out every day with large groups of people. But you do need a certain degree of socializing with 1 or 2 friends. Being on your own ALL the time ain’t good for you, even introverts.

Also, the final point might be puzzling: “avoid 100% cutting anything from your diet”.

Here’s the thing: the data seem to show that those who follow a more 80/20 way of eating - where 80+% of calories come from nutritious food while the rest comes from “less nutritious” food - have the best chance of keeping the weight off long-term. Mostly because, for the majority of us, it’s a more sustainable way of eating than something more extreme like completely eliminating sugar or processed food.

The only kinds of food you should 100% avoid are:

- Foods you don’t like.
- Foods you’re allergic to.
- Foods your doctor has said you need to avoid.

Practice moderation ❤️

it should go without saying that if a Netflix documentary helps you make a clearly obvious positive change like eating more veggies or starting to exercise, then awesome. I’m not talking about that. There are tons of problems with that documentary - find Layne Norton’s breakdown of it on his blog.

Neflix nutrition documentaries are NOT scientific. The creators are very selective with the evidence they use to present their story (google “confirmation bias”) and too many of their examples are anecdotal. Sure, use these documentaries as a *springboard for further research* (I recommend talking to a doctor or dietician if you don’t have a science background) but don’t suddenly change everything you eat just because you watched a 90-minute documentary claiming meat is the source of all your problems.

Muscle doesn’t weigh more than fat - it’s *more dense*. This means that a pound of muscle takes up less space than a pound of fat. But a pound of muscle and a pound of fat both weigh… one pound.

Cardio doesn’t really impact weight loss much. When the machine says you burned 400 calories, you’re lucky if it was even HALF that amount. But cardio is underrated for health, so do it anyway.

All the evidence we have indicates that eating more veggies makes weight loss easier and leads to better long-term health outcomes. Broccoli ain’t fucking poisonous 🤦‍♂️

The only (non-surgical) way anyone ever lost fat was by being in a calorie deficit. Because it’s the only way fat loss happens.

Listen: I’m not saying you *should* overeat by 1000 calories 6x per month.

I’m not an advocate for “cheat days”. I’m an advocate for moderation.

I’m simply saying you would still see results if you slipped up 6 times in 30 days and overate by 1000 calories.

Let’s do the math…

24 days a month you manage to end the day at a deficit of around 500 calories.

Nice work 👊

24 x 500 = 12,000. This is your total deficit those days.

The other days you overeat by a thousand calories, ending the day at a surplus of 500 calories (your goal is a 500-cal deficit, you overshoot by 1000, you end up with a 500-cal surplus).

6 x 500 = 3000.

Your net deficit for those 30 days is:

12,000 - 3000 = 9000 calories.

Which means you can still lose over 2 pounds of fat in that period even with 6 “f*ckups”.

Sure, the scale might not budge, but that’ll be due to the extra water retention from those days. Getting back on track is all you need to do to get rid of the extra water.

And this is the power of consistency over perfection. If you can be on point 80% of the time, it’s very hard to undo that work the remaining 20% of the time. Plus it will REALLY help remove some of the rigidity you may be feeling with your diet - flexibility usually helps us feel more relaxed about the process, which can be huge for developing the mindset of sustainability.

The key is to not let the occasional day where you slip up turn into WEEKS of slipping up. If you’re currently in this position after the holiday weekend, remember, you’re just one decision away from getting back on track.

The first 6 items cause water retention.

You don’t need to do anything about it. Just stick with your regular habits and it will take care of itself.

Number 7 is simply having more undigested food in your system than normal PLUS some water retention. Undigested food has mass, which will contribute a little to the number on the scale.

Number 8, eating more food than usual, can also be undigested food sitting in your system. For example, if you had a HUGE salad last night while staying within calories, some of that plant matter is going to still be in your digestive system.

And if you went over calories, you probably consumed more carbs and salt - which will cause water weight. Is any of it going to be stored as fat? Well, even if you went 1000 calories over maintenance, that would only be around 0.3 lbs of fat that you gained. If this happened yesterday, don’t undereat today - you’ll just get hungry and overeat again. Stick with your regular calorie intake and your regular habits - after a few days, that will have taken care of any additional fat you gained (assuming you’re in a fat loss phase and you’re in a calorie deficit).

Sure, there are exceptions to this.

Like someone living with lipodema, where fat loss in certain spots won’t happen even when they’re in a genuine calorie deficit.

I’m not, of course, talking to people impacted by this or any similar conditions.

But for everyone else, not seeing weight loss - or inch loss - is due to not being in a calorie deficit.

Because being in a calorie deficit is the only way to lose weight and inches.

Stated more accurately, being in a calorie deficit is the only way to lose fat.

Now, before you ask: with medical issues like PCOS and hypothyroidism, you would still need to be in a calorie deficit to lose fat - but what “should” be a calorie deficit is often much lower than you would expect, because these issues can/will reduce your BMR.

And that’s why anyone with hypothyroidism, PCOS, or similar should talk to their doctor or a dietician - you might need medication to manage the issue, a specific dietary intervention, or both.

And for everyone else: if you’re not getting results, address the following…

- Track calories
- Track calories *accurately* (food scale, measuring cups, measuring spoons, etc.)
- Work out 3-5x per week
- Get 7K+ steps per day
- Be consistent on weekends too

To anyone who thinks I’m saying that calories are the ONLY thing that matter: spend a few minutes looking at my posts. Look at how much emphasis I place on eating nutritious food, protein, getting enough sleep, and managing stress.

Saying calories are the only thing that matter for fat loss is about as silly as saying that hormones are the only thing that matter for fat loss.

You need to eat nutritious food and plenty of protein to make sure you can bring those hunger hormones under control.

But if you eat too many calories of nutritious food, you won’t lose fat.

Enough with the black-and-white thinking please 🙏

But they ain’t necessary.

And there’s no “damage” that you need to “undo”.

You just need to get back on track.

And remember: getting back on track does NOT mean doing anything extreme.

It just means going back to your regular habits.

Which should look something like this:

✅ Eat fruit and veggies
✅ Eat protein and healthy fats
✅ Eat carbs
✅ Drink plenty of water
✅ Get at least 80% of calories from nutritious food and up to 20% from less nutritious food

None of this is easy.

The calorie deficit, the protein, the walking, the going to bed early, the strength training…

You can’t rely on motivation to get you through because you won’t always feel motivated.

Especially after the initial excitement of following a plan for the first week or 2.

Yes, motivation is important, and you should do as much as possible to maintain motivation.

But you have to accept the fact that you will NOT always feel motivated.

Some days you’re not gonna want to work out.

When that happens, examine what’s going on.

Sometimes you’ll realize you might have overdone it recently and rest is the better choice.

Maybe you’re running on an hour of sleep due to an emergency - fine, skipping a workout would be justified.

Or maybe you’re sick or injured - yeah, don’t fucking work out in that situation.

But sometimes you’ll realize “oh, nothing’s happening, I just don’t wanna work out right now.”

In that situation, say to yourself “OK, I don’t wanna work out, but I’m gonna do it anyway.”

And then go fucking do it.

Sure, you can try reminding yourself of the reasons you’re working out - “I want to be stronger.” “I want to model good habits for my kids.” “I want to be around for long enough to see grandkids.” - but you are simply not going to want to work out on some days.

Work out anyway 🤷‍♂️

You need to be consistent enough for long enough for these habits to become deeply engrained - if you keep stopping when you’re not motivated, you’ll never form the habit.

Why would that be a problem? Because you need these habits in place to both lose the weight AND keep it off. These are long-term habits, so you need to make the effort.

This is the “secret” of those who maintain their results for a long time - they get it done even when don’t feel motivated.

And you know what… sometimes the workout you do when you’re not motivated becomes an AWESOME workout.

You won’t regret making the hard choice of working out. But you’ll probably regret the easy choice of not working out.

Type “478 breathing” into YouTube for tons of demo videos. Also, don’t be the idiot who does deep breathing exercises in water - in case you pass out.

Here’s why these would be my top picks…

And by the way, don’t ask me for brands.

Just find well-reviewed products on Amazon or your website of choice.
 
 
- Adjustable dumbbells. 1 pair of adjustable dumbbells can replace 10-15 pairs of fixed weight dumbbells. And it’s also WAY cheaper to buy adjustable dumbbells.

Now, that isn’t to say they’re necessarily cheap. You’re still looking at $300+ (USD) for a pair of adjustable dumbbells going up to 50 lbs each. But if you treat them well, they’ll last a LONG time.

And before anyone asks “should women should buy dumbbells this heavy too?” my answer is YES 100%. In my experience as a coach, many women don’t realize how strong they’re capable of becoming.
 
 
- Adjustable bench. Get one that folds (for easy storage) and that can also incline and decline. An adjustable bench will open your workouts up to SO many exercises: chest press, incline overhead press, step up, hip thrust, etc.

You can probably find a decent one for $150+ (USD). And don’t bother with one that has a bunch of cables and leg extension attachments. Keep it simple.
 
 
- Suspension trainer (aka TRX). If you only have the budget for one piece of equipment, this is a great one. It’ll set you back around $50+ (USD).

The brand TRX is by far the most popular brand of suspension trainer - in fact, most people refer to their suspension trainer as their “TRX” even if it’s a different brand.
 
 
Now, I understand that not everyone will have the budget even for a suspension trainer. If that’s you, keep on going with the equipment you already have and keep an eye on Craigslist and Facebook Marketplace in case any deals come up.

And you can always google “bodyweight strength training” or join a cheap local gym if there’s one nearby.

There’s always *something* you can do, even with a limited budget.

But for those people who are fortunate enough to be able to invest in some equipment: adjustable dumbbells, an adjustable bench, and a suspension trainer would be my top 3 picks for a beginner-friendly home gym that doesn’t take up a ton of space.

There’s so much shit fitness advice on Instagram.

And even the “good” advice won’t always be appropriate for you to follow.

For example, someone who’s only getting 6 hours of sleep shouldn’t follow the “get up early to train” advice.

And someone who’s doing 6 HIIT workouts a week doesn’t need the “push harder in workouts” advice.

This might sound obvious - but only when you’re looking at other people.

It’s easy to look at what others are doing, especially at what they’re doing wrong. It’s way harder to turn that gaze inwards and reconsider what *we’re* doing.

Mostly because we don’t want to have to acknowledge that we might be doing something wrong.

And that’s why people hire coaches - to help them figure out which advice they need to listen to without making them feel like an idiot.

Some of my clients need help going from 0 to 2 workouts a week.

Others need help going from 7 to 4 workouts a week.

Sone clients need help figuring out how to eat more veggies.

Others need help with introducing “less nutritious” food into their diet without feeling guilty about it.

Every one of us is at a different point on our fitness journeys. How we keep making progress from our unique points is going to look slightly different for each person.

If you’re having trouble figuring out what you need, try journaling. Try talking to someone you know who’s knowledgeable about fitness and nutrition.

Or try hiring a coach.

1. Aim for 7-10K steps per day.

2. Managing stress can reduce stress-eating. Download Headspace or a similar app and get to work.

3. More sleep = less hunger. The easiest way to get more sleep is to go to bed earlier. And stop using your fucking phone in bed - it’s ruining your sleep quality.

4. Get 80% or more of calories from nutritious food, and the remaining from “less nutritious” food. This teaches you no food is good or bad, which gives you far more calories control over what and how much you eat.

5. Unless your goal weight is 100 lbs, which is inappropriate for pretty much anyone over 5ft, 1200 calories isn’t enough. Undereating leads to overeating, so stop that shit. For weight loss, eat approx [target weight in lbs x12] calories per day. And no, you don’t need to deduct 500 from that number.

6. You need to lift weights. And I mean heavy weights, not the 10 lb dumbbells you use in that class you go to or in the videos you follow along to. Those things are basically cardio anyway. Lifting weights will build muscle, which is an ESSENTIAL part of looking toned. If you don’t know how to strength train, go to rosentrain.con/strength - sign up for my newsletter and I’ll send you my FREE “Beginner’s Guide to Strength Training”.

7. Alcohol wrecks sleep quality, so limit your intake. Water will make you feel more awake and like you have more energy, which makes it more likely you’ll get up and move around. If your pee is dark orange, you need more water. If it’s a pale straw colour, you’re good.

8. Protein reduces hunger and prevents muscle loss. [Target weight in lbs x 0.7-1] grams per day is a good aim. The fiber in fruit and veggies makes you feel full, not to mention the health benefits of it. Women need 21-25g per day, and men need 30-38g per day. If you’re a beginner losing inches but not weight…

Keep doing what you’re doing. Because inch loss = fat loss, and fat loss without a change on the scale means you’re ALSO building muscle.

Good work 🙌

If the lack of progress on the scale upsets you during this time, remind yourself why the scale isn’t moving - you’re building muscle, which will make you look leaner AND increase your resting metabolic rate.

Let me say that again - you’re going to soon look leaner AND you’ll be burning more calories at rest.

And if that doesn’t help, take a break from the scale and focus on using measurements and clothing fit to determine progress.

Quick note: I said only beginners can build muscle in a calorie deficit. However, those with a very significant amount of weight to lose can do so too. Also, if you’ve lost muscle in the past (typically this happens after taking a long break from strength training or after yo yo dieting) you can easily REbuild muscle in a calorie deficit.

As can people using “special” supplements, which I would not recommend.

The rest of us will get MUCH better results if we focus on EITHER fat loss OR building muscle.

The underrated stuff works best, but it sounds kinda boring.

The overrated stuff is the stuff that *can* have an effect, but isn’t very sustainable for most of us and therefore only really works for a short period of time - and that’s if you have all the foundational boring work in place.

Put it this way: if you’re completely sedentary right now and you also have a desk job which has led to tight hips and shoulders, trying to do a HIIT class with a ton of burpees right now is a bad fucking idea.

Ease into that kind of thing - if that’s the path you even want to take. HIIT workouts can be great for overall conditioning, and you might even find them fun - which are great reasons to do them. But focusing on using HIIT - or *any* form of cardio - for fat loss won’t end well.

And if you haven’t worked on the skill of eating fruit or veggies with every meal, you’re probably not in a good position to go keto or follow ANY excessively restrictive diet. And anyway, restrictive diets like keto are 100% unnecessary (yes, I know, some people with medical conditions need to follow them).

Also, I wouldn’t ever advise working out daily - you’re just asking for an overuse injury.

Fasted cardio doesn’t accelerate fat loss. The only reason to do it would be if you feel good doing it. Or if you train early and you don’t have time to eat before the workout.

As for the useless stuff: it’s a waste of money at best, and dangerous at worst. Even if it works while you’re doing it, the results won’t last, and the risks aren’t worth it. Stay the fuck away.

I know EXACTLY what you’re gonna say…

“But Daniel, I do so badly at those holiday events that it undoes my progress!”

Well, it sounds like you need to stop treating every single one of those events as a special occasion and instead treat most of them as *social* occasions. At special occasions - like Thanksgiving or Christmas Day - it’s appropriate to indulge and go into a surplus if you choose to. At social occasions it’s appropriate to go up to maintenance, but not to treat them as free-for-alls. Don’t eat the same way at your office Christmas party as you would on Christmas Day with your family.
 
 
“But Daniel, if I keep going up to maintenance I won’t see results - what’s the point in trying?”

It sounds like you have an all-or-nothing mentality - which is one reason you’re not getting results that stick.

You’re forgetting that having an 80/20, more moderate approach to food is how you’re going to both lose weight AND keep it off.

View the next 12 weeks as practice for maintaining your weight - or, at the very least, minimizing weight gain.
 
 
“But Daniel, you’re forgetting about all the temptations - the snack food in the office, the Halloween candy at home, and all the other delicious holiday treats!”

Figure out ways to include small amounts of that kind of food in your day-to-day diet - pre-tracking each day in MyFitnessPal will help.

You can also choose a desk away from the snack food, or request it be moved away from you.

At home, don’t keep the tempting food out on the counter. Store it on the top shelf of your cupboard behind other food - make it so you need to use a stepladder to reach it.
 
 
Look. This is going to take work. It’s going to take effort. And it’s going to take discipline.

But if you let everything drop now, it’s going to make life so much more difficult in January when you’re trying to get back on track.

You don’t need to be perfect.

Just promise yourself that you’re going to make the effort with as many of your regular meals as possible.

Then you’ll be able to enjoy the holiday events that much more.

#weightlossadvice #weightlosscoaching #weightlossforwomen #weightlossformoms

READ THE CAPTION.

This is called an *abundance mindset*

An abundance mindset will make your weight loss journey so much more sustainable and misery-free.

Instead of focusing on a ridiculously low and ARBITRARY calorie intake like 1200 calories, here’s what you’re gonna do:

- take your target weight in lbs
- multiply by 12
- eat that many calories per day, plus or minus 100 calories

(No, you don’t need to deduct 500 from that number.)

Don’t think of it as your “maximum” calorie goal; instead, your daily mission is to eat within 100 calories of that number.

So if your goal is 150 lbs, your target is 1800 (150 x 12) calories per day.

And your daily range is 1700-1900 calories per day.

Finish each day in that range while also getting 7K+ steps per day, strength training 2-3x per week, and doing some cardio - and you’ll have a better chance of being consistent enough for long enough to see results.

If you try to force yourself to stick with fewer calories than your range and you’re chronically hungry, stop. That isn’t a “better” day - you’re making things way harder than they need to be, and you’ll be more likely to overeat in the near future future - undoing any kind of progress you made.

But a day where you finish within your range and you feel satiated - that’s a fucking win. You can keep that up for a damn long time - long enough to see results ❤️
 
 
P.S. if this sounds like it won’t be enough calories (because, for example, you’re super active) then eat a little more and see how you feel. If this sounds like too many calories, what do you have to lose by trying? You can adjust as needed if you don’t see results.
 

P.P.S. this means some smaller people might need to aim for approx 1200 cals - basically anyone with a target weight of 100 lbs, which also means you’ll be around 5’0” tall. If that describes you and 1200 sounds horrible, consider increasing steps to 10-15K and add an additional 100-300 cals.
 
 
P.P.P.S this is a general formula that won’t work for EVERYONE. You don’t need to point out the obvious. 

 
 
 
#weightlossadvice #weightlosstip #weightlosstipsforwomen #weightlossformoms

This is a “what NOT to do” list.

Here are a few notes:

- Staying up late and not getting enough sleep will make you hungry because lack of sleep makes your body release more ghrelin (the hormone that makes you hungry) and less leptin (the hormone that makes you feel full).

- Cardio is fine to do. It’s super healthy and we should all be doing it. But we need to strength train while losing weight to make sure we don’t lose muscle (and end up looking skinny-fat).

- Scheduling workouts gives you a better chance of actually doing them. Put them in your calendar.

- It’s fine to go up to maintenance on weekends (use any online TDEE calculator to calculate your maintenance requirements), but if you treat the weekend as a free-for-all you’re gonna undo any progress you made that week.

- Unless you’re very small (ie your goal weight is around 100 lbs), you almost certainly need more than 1200 calories to lose weight. Target weight in lbs x12 is a good ballpark figure for weight loss.

- If I only trained when I felt motivated I’d train twice a year. The difference between someone who loses weight successfully and someone who doesn’t is a willingness to do the hard work even when they don’t want to.

- Taking measurements is a better way of tracking fat loss, especially if you’ve just started strength training. Go to rosentrain.com/strength and sign up for my newsletter - you’ll receive my FREE Beginner’s Guide to Strength Training ebook, and inside I tell you which measurements to take.

 
 
 
#weightlosstips #weightlossadvice #weightlossformoms #weightlossforwomen #weightlosscoaching

When I say these things don’t take talent, I don’t mean they’re necessarily easy.

I’m simply pointing out that pretty much anyone can form these habits one by one with a few weeks - or months - of effort.
 
 
1. The best way to get more sleep - which will lower levels of the hormone that makes you hungry (ghrelin) - is to simply go to bed earlier. Yes, I know that shift workers can’t be in bed by 10pm. I don’t literally mean go to bed by 10pm… I mean stop staying up so fucking late. And don’t give me that “I need me time” shit - first, you don’t need 3 hours of “me time”. One hour is plenty. And second, going to bed earlier will probably give you time to work out in the morning. THAT can be your “me time”.

2. Having set meal times will regulate hunger. If you have regular meal times your body will soon learn when to expect food, and it will then start pumping out those hunger hormones at appropriate times.

3. Pre-tracking food does two things. First it means you don’t need to pull out your phone and decide what to eat several times a day, saving you time and effort. And second, it means you’ll know if you’re in a calorie deficit or not for the day - it makes no fucking sense to track your food AFTER eating it and finding out you went way over your calories. Block off time either the morning of or the night before to pre-track the coming day’s food.

4. Scheduling your workouts is a way of committing to doing them. If you’re not currently being consistent with your workouts, schedule them. Just telling yourself you’ll figure it out on the day is why you’re not getting it done.

5. Stop using your fucking phone in bed. Mindless scrolling will make your sleep quality worse, even if you have no problem falling asleep -because you’re overloading your brain with information when you’re supposed to be in a relaxed state, and a relaxed state is one where you’re NOT consuming large amounts of information. Stick with reading a book. Or consider some meditation or breathing exercises.

If you love boot camps, make that your focus. Again, great habit.

Enjoying the process makes the process more sustainable.

But whatever you do…

You need to strength train. AT LEAST 1-2x per week.

And frankly, 1x per week might not be enough for you in the long-term.

Strength training improves bone density.

It can improve flexibility and mobility.

It can improve your quality of life as you age.

And, for weight loss, it will help prevent muscle loss in a calorie deficit.

Boot camps, barre, yoga, following YouTube videos, etc. are NOT strength training. There’s no progressive overload and it’s EXTREMELY unlikely you’re lifting heavy enough weights with sufficient intensity to stimulate the body to preserve its muscle in a calorie deficit.

And when I say “sufficient intensity” I’m not talking about being out of breath or sweating or achieving a certain heart rate. I’m talking about going close to failure with a particular exercise, only stopping when you think you can squeeze 2 more reps before you fail.

If you’re wondering whether the exercise class you’re doing counts as strength training, it doesn’t. Please don’t ask.

I didn’t say you had to enjoy it. You just need to enjoy the overall *process*.
