Discipline is important.

It’s REQUIRED if you want to successfully do hard things.

But lack of discipline is rarely the issue with those who can’t lose weight. Sure, it’s SOMETIMES the issue, but it’s usually more about hunger, mindset, and poor habits.

Here’s what to address…

- More fiber will help you feel full. Women need around 21-25g per day, and men need around 30-38g. Fiber basically means “more fruit and veggies”; more plant-based food in general.

- Good sleep will increase levels of the hormone that make you feel full (leptin) and decreases levels of the hormone that makes you feel hungry (ghrelin).

- Protein is INCREDIBLE at reducing hunger. Aim for [target weight in lbs x 0.7-1] grams per day. So if your goal weight is 150 lbs, aim for 105-150g protein per day.

- Undereating will also increase hunger. Instead of eating 1200 calories, aim for [target weight in lbs x12] calories per day. Also, eat more of your damn calories at breakfast and lunch - it’s why you keep overeating at night.

- Have more flexibility with food; instead of trying to eliminate processed foods (which usually leads to overeating processed foods on the weekend) include a little several times a week (up to 20% of your daily intake).

- Daily movement and stress management are linked. Going for a daily walk is going to be HUGE for helping you manage stress, which can reduce stress eating. If that alone doesn’t work, try journaling, meditation, breathing exercises, or therapy.

You know those 12-week transformations where the person looked AMAZING after 12 weeks?

It didn’t actually take 12 weeks.

Sure, there was probably 12 weeks between the photos, but that’s not what I mean.

I mean the person - male OR female - who looked super lean and toned after 12 weeks had already spent years in the gym, lifting heavy weights and *building muscle*.

Because looking toned has 2 components:

1. Reducing body fat.

2. Increasing muscle size to give limbs shape and definition.

Their 12-week transformation was basically a 12-week fat loss phase.

But they weren’t a beginner.

For a beginner to look like that will take a lot closer to 12 MONTHS, maybe longer. Because while a beginner can absolutely build muscle in a calorie deficit, very few beginners will build enough muscle in a deficit to have achieved their “end-body” after 12 weeks. In reality, they would probably need to alternate between periods in a deficit to lose fat and periods at maintenance to build muscle.

And once you have enough experience of strength training (at least 1 year of consistent work), you’ll probably need to be in a slight surplus to build muscle.

So, at some point, you’ll need to come out of a deficit to get the results you want.

How do you know when? I’d say when you’re close to your goal weight but you can’t see the tone you want. That’s going to be different for every person.

Here’s why…

There are no secrets.

To lose weight, you need to do this:

- Be in a calorie deficit
- Strength train 2-4x per week
- Eat plenty of protein, fruit, and veggies
- Get 7-10K steps per day
- Follow the 80/20 guideline (get at least 80% of your calories from nutritious food and up to 20% from less nutritious food)
- Get 7-9 hours of sleep
- Manage stress
- Do some cardio 1-3x per week (although this is more for general health than weight loss)

You don’t need to cut out entire food groups, you don’t need to calorie cycle, you don’t need an uneducated influencer’s “hormone-balancing” diet, you don’t need intermittent fasting, you don’t need to do 5 HIIT workouts per week, and you don’t need to carb cycle.

Unless you enjoy doing those things. Or you have a specific medical reason to do them.

Otherwise, they are not required for weight loss.

But this raises the question…

Good question.

The value of coaching is a combination of accountability (someone checking in on you regularly to make sure you’re doing what you said you would do), ongoing support, and help with the IMPLEMENTATION of the habits I listed above - listening to you, finding out about your current situation, and figuring out ways to overcome the obstacles that are stopping you from doing this on your own.

I used to believe every single thing on this list.

Which is why my results used to be temporary.

And why my weight yo-yo’d in my twenties.

It was only when I accepted that what I was doing wasn’t working that I was able to educate myself…

1) When calories are matched, meal frequency has no impact on either your metabolism or your rate of fat loss. Your total calorie intake determines your rate of fat loss.

2) Squats are only bad for your knees if you already have bad knees. And performing squats with shit technique is also bad for your knees.

3) When calories are matched, high-carb and low-carb diets lead to the same outcome. Your carb intake comes down to personal preference. Yes, some people experience increased appetite on a high carb diet. Others experience the opposite. And for others, it makes no difference.

4) The best thing for fat loss is a calorie deficit, whether you’re doing HIIT workouts or not.

5) As long as you’re in a calorie deficit, you could eat a sugar-only diet and still lose fat. Would that be a good idea? Fuck no. That would be a tremendously bad idea.You’ll be chronically hungry and your health will suffer enormously. Eat your fruit and veggies. But know that eating sugar in a calorie deficit will still lead to fat loss.

6) Your rate of sweating indicates your rate of effort and your temperature, which won’t have any impact on fat loss if you’re not in a calorie deficit. And if you’re in a calorie deficit, you’ll lose fat whether you sweat or not. Train for the right reasons: strength train to get stronger, do cardio for lung and heart health, and go on walks to manage stress. Not because “it burns calories”.

Counting calories is a very efficient way of getting into a calorie deficit and losing weight.

I think it’s the MOST efficient way.

But it isn’t the ONLY way.

Tracking calories isn’t appropriate for everyone. Maybe it feels too tedious or it makes you too obsessive or you’re just not a numbers person.

If that describes you, this post is for you.

And by the way: this assumes you’re working out 3-5x per week and getting 7-10K steps per day. If you don’t do that - start.
 
 
✅ Eat 3 meals per day. 1/2 the plate should be covered by veggies, 1/4 by your protein source, and a 1/4 by your carb source. Stop eating when you’re 80% full (yes, this is subjective), eat slowly, and drink a glass of water before and after each meal.

If you’re concerned by the lack of mention of fat, bear in mind that most meat and fish contains plenty of fat anyway - and don’t forget about cooking oil. But feel free to add a little healthy fat 😊

Also: don’t cheat by buying a giant plate 😂
 
 
✅ Drink [half your bodyweight in lbs] oz water per day. That’s an approximate aim - individual requirements will vary. And most people probably won’t need more than 100oz.

Monitor your pee: dark orange = drink more water. Pale yellow = you’re good.

You can also drink black coffee, herbal tea, and zero-calorie soda as needed.
 
 
✅ Snacks and alcohol are fine in moderation. Although I don’t recommend having more than 1 drink every day - it’ll impact sleep.
 
 
✅ When in restaurants, ask for sauces and dressings on the side.

When in doubt, ask for a salad.

Skip dessert, unless you REALLY want it, in which case you can count it as 2 snacks.

And DON’T feel obligated to “get your money’s worth” and clear your plate. If you’re not hungry, stop eating.

And the same goes with ANY meal - stop eating if you’re no longer hungry.

Also: if you REALLY want the dessert AND some wine AND your snacks for the day… lol go ahead. Just get back on track tomorrow.

1. Bulgarian split squats. Need I say more?

2. Having a “2-plate” deadlift, squat, or bench press refers to there being 2x 45 lb plates (weights)on EACH side of the bar. Then we add the weight of the bar, which is almost always 45 lbs. Total = 225 lbs.

3. Once you’ve started a program, stick to it! It’s been written with the intention of you following it for its full duration, which is what you would need to do for results. “Get Started” Plan in the caption 👇
 
 
 
Enough with the extreme diets.

Enough with the hours of exercise.

And enough with trying to do everything all at once.

If you’ve been unsuccessfully trying to lose weight for longer than a year - or if you lost the weight but you then regained it - there’s a good chance you’re trying to do it too quickly.

You try something extreme for a few weeks, lose a BUNCH of weight, stop the extreme method… and you then regain the weight once you return to your old habits.

Instead, let it be slower.

This time, focus on forming sustainable habits that you can see yourself following for LIFE.

Reset your expectations - fuck those 90-day transformations.

Give yourself a full fucking YEAR.

Spend the next 3-4 months focusing on habit change, and the rest of the year on being consistent with those new habits.

Focus on 1 habit at a time, only introducing an additional habit when you’re 1000% confident the previous habit is deeply ingrained.

The next year could look like this:

Month 1: work up to getting 7K steps a day.

Month 2: work up to 2-3 workouts per week

Month 3: eat more protein and veggies

Month 4: track food and get into a moderate calorie deficit (target weight in lbs x12 is a good goal that puts pretty much all moderately active people in a calorie deficit).

Months 5-12: ruthlessly execute on your habits every fucking day.

End of month 12: feel shock at the incredible progress you’ve made over the last year AND be in no doubt these are permanent changes.

You’ve got this 👊

If you’re a beginner and you’re losing inches but not weight…

Keep doing what you’re doing. Because inch loss = fat loss, and fat loss without a change on the scale means you’re ALSO building muscle.

The rest of us will get MUCH better results if we focus on EITHER fat loss OR building muscle.

1) Strength workouts don’t need to be 3-hours long. You don’t need crazy exercises that involve a bosu ball. You can get a GREAT workout in under an hour with just 5 simple exercises:

- A hip hinge (deadlift / hip thrust / glute bridge variations).
- A squat or lunge.
- An upper body push (chest press, shoulder press, etc.)
- An upper body pull (dumbbell row, cable row, etc.)
- A core exercise (planks, dead bugs, loaded carries, etc.)

That’ll take less than an hour. Even less if you perform supersets or trisets.
 
 
2) You don’t need to strength train every day. 3-4x per week is optimal, and 2x per week is great for beginners or for a busy period of your life.

- 2 workouts per week: 2x full-body.
- 3 workouts per week: 1 x full-body, 1x upper, 1x lower.
- 4 workouts per week: 2x upper, 2x lower.
 
 
3) Get your 7-10K steps per day. If you’re trying to lose fat, it burns a ton of calories. Walking is awesome for stress management. And there are tons of health benefits of walking this much daily.

5. This ice bath trend is fucking stupid. Sure, I get it that some are doing it because it’s good to do hard things. Cool. Plus the studies seem to show that taking an ice bath after a workout can actually limit muscle growth (if hypertrophy is your goal). So next time your gym asks if you’d like to spend 50 bucks for the pleasure of spending 2 minutes in their tub of ice cubes, tell them you’re just gonna go home to take a nap instead - it will do more for your recovery than the fucking bath.

Yes, weight loss is simple, but…

“Simple” and “easy” are NOT synonyms.

Expecting weight loss to be easy - EVEN when working with a coach - is unrealistic.

Sure, a coach is there to help you come up with a plan, discuss ways around any obstacles, and keep you accountable - but YOU are the one who has to do the work.

And that’s all there is - the work.

Sure, you can make life a little easiER on yourself by scheduling workouts, blocking off time for walks, meal prepping on the weekend, pre-tracking food in MyFitnessPal each morning…

But then you actually have to go DO those things.

That is NOT easy.

However…

It’s weird, but if you tell yourself it’s SUPPOSED to be difficult and it’s totally NORMAL that you’re struggling… it kinda starts to feel a little easier.

As the great Jerzy Gregorek says:

“Hard choices, easy life. Easy choices, hard life.”

If you can truly accept that weight loss is going to be difficult and that you’re meant to be making the hard choices, you’ll feel a TON better about the process.

You won’t be perfect (nor should you be) and it will take time - but this small change in mindset might just make this weight-loss attempt your most successful attempt yet ❤️

And even more good news: it WILL become easier with time. You just need to put the hard work in for the first few months.

6. Fruit doesn’t cause weight gain.

Sure, *too many calories* worth of fruit will cause weight gain.

But not because fruit is inherently “fattening” (I really hate that word), but because you consumed enough calories to put you in a calorie surplus, which caused the weight gain.

Once a month AT MOST.

I work out 12x per month.

3x per week.

Of those 12 workouts, I feel motivated to do 1, where I’m really looking forward to doing the workout.

Then there are 10 where I basically punch in, do the work, and punch out. I’m not looking forward to the workout, but I’m not dreading it either. On those days, there are definitely more fun ways I could choose to spend my time, but I go to the gym anyway.

This is what happens when you’ve been consistent with workouts for at least a few months - you’re not motivated to do them, but you don’t dread them either. They’re *tolerable*. It becomes a thing you do for your health and wellness, just part of your routine.

You soon find ways of making them even more tolerable - you listen to music, podcasts, audiobooks, etc. while you’re training.

And then there’s 1 workout a month - sometimes 2 - where I REALLY don’t want to train. I’m not in the mood, or maybe I’m a little tired, or maybe the weather is horrible. But I usually work out anyway.

This is why relying on motivation will get you nowhere. Think of it this way: you’re not motivated to brush your teeth, but you do it anyway.

Go to the gym, do SOMETHING, and do it consistently.

That’s the secret: doing SOMETHING consistently and not worrying about it being perfect.

EXPLAINED IN THE CAPTION 👇

1. Doing more than 5 workouts per week is 100% unnecessary. Especially if you’re a parent over 40 with a full time job - you’re probably not going to be able to properly recover from that many workouts each week, which will make you feel chronically tired.

2. There’s no evidence that working out on an empty stomach leads to more fat loss. If you enjoy working out fasted, cool, just know it isn’t a requirement.

3. The only way ANY diet has EVER resulted in fat loss was by putting the dieter in a calorie deficit, whether intended or not.

4. It’s easy to overeat by THOUSANDS of calories on weekends if you’re not paying attention (and drinking to excess).

5. NEAT - non-exercise activity thermogenesis, basically any kind of movement that isn’t a formal “workout” - is responsible for far more of your fat loss than your workouts. In fact, the data indicate that getting 7-10K steps per day can burn up to 3x as many calories as your average workout. If you’re getting fewer steps than that and you’re not getting results, increase steps before you increase workout frequency. Plus getting 7-10K steps per day is a super healthy habit.

-

1) When you perform the target weight in lbs x12 calculation, you can then calculate a target calorie range. If I was aiming for 1800 calories per day, I would aim for 100 calories either side of that number: 1700-1900 calories.

2) If you’ve performed the above calculation and it doesn’t seem like enough, then just add 100-300 calories.

3) If you’ve performed the above calculation and it seems like too many calories, you’re probably used to thinking you have to eat 1200 calories to lose weight. The calculation is also best for someone who’s aiming for a weight that would be considered by a doctor to be within a healthy range for their height. You can use Google to find out those weight ranges.

4) Don’t try to start doing EVERYTHING at once. Pick no more than two things at a time (one is better) and spend at least 1-2 weeks doing it before introducing another habit. And if you’re getting nowhere near 7-10K steps right now, I would increase by 1K every 1-2 weeks until I hit that range. So if I was currently at 2K, I would aim for 3K for 1-2 weeks, then 4K for 1-2 weeks, etc.

Here’s why 👇

1) More sleep = less hunger. And more sleep means you’ll be more willing to get up, move around, and work out.

2) More protein = less hunger. It will also prevent muscle loss, which means your metabolism will remain high AND you get that toned look (don’t forget to also strength train for the same muscle-preserving and toning effects).

3) If you’re not getting results but your calorie intake is on point, it might be due to lack of daily movement. Get to the 7-10K steps per day range.

4) If you keep missing workouts, you’re not getting steps, and you don’t have your ingredients prepped to cook healthy meals, try SCHEDULING all these things in your calendar app. You’ll at least triple your chance of success.

5) The solution to stress-eating isn’t a new diet - the solution is to manage stress better. Go on walks, journal, meditate, etc. And make sure you do it EVERY day, even if stress is low.

6) The only foods you need to eliminate are those you dislike, those you’re allergic to, and those your doctor has told you to stop eating. Completely eliminating sugar and processed food just isn’t realistic for 99.9% of us. But an 80/20 approach - where you get at least 80% of your calories from more nutritious food and up to 20% of your calories from less nutritious food - is way more realistic. And DO NOT keep the less nutritious food for the weekend, because you WILL overeat it. Try to incorporate small amounts through the week alongside your mostly nutritious diet.

If yesterday’s nutrition didn’t go according to plan, don’t use that as an excuse to give up until Monday.

Because one meal or one day off track won’t ruin your progress.

Seriously. I know it feels like you gained a ton of weight overnight, but you didn’t - it’s at least 90% water weight.

But letting one day turn into two days off track CAN stop progress.

I often advise clients to choose to go up to maintenance - in other words, a planned and intentional higher-calorie day - 1-2x per week so they can incorporate family pizza night, a meal out, a client dinner, etc. We make it part of the plan.

And if they’ve told me about a previous “I’ll just wait until Monday” mindset, I also advise that it’s important to plan the next day’s meals too - so that, whatever happens, they have no choice but to get back on track the next day.

And don’t be too extreme - don’t skip meals or spend hours on the elliptical. Even if yesterday went super wrong, today consume your regular calorie goal, get your steps, and only work out if you normally work out on a Sunday. Because undereating and overexercising can cause a ton of hunger and make you eat more than you wanted.

Just spend some time thinking about what caused the deviation from the plan yesterday.

Use it as an opportunity to learn.

And go back to your regular habits today.

❤️

Is it always this easy?

No, of course not.

There’s a chance that the proteins you’re focused on are fairly high-calorie proteins, and so performing this exercise won’t work well.

For example, if you’re currently eating 2 eggs for breakfast, you’d need to eat 5 to hit 30g protein (around a third of most people’s bare-minimum protein target during weight loss).

In this case, you would be better off adding a lean protein like egg whites (you can buy containers of egg whites from most grocery stores) to the 2 eggs.

And sometimes switching from a lower-protein version to a high-protein version of a food (e.g. switching from regular yogurt to Greek yogurt) is the better option.

Otherwise all you’d end up eating would be high-fat protein sources and veggies. Which wouldn’t be too fun.

If you’re already eating lean proteins (Green yogurt, white fish, chicken breast, cottage cheese, etc. - google “lean proteins” for more examples) then going through the 5 steps can be useful.

Just make sure you don’t cut out all the fat - remember, we need to make sure we’re getting at least 20% of our daily calories from fat for general health.
